On Thu, Apr 7, 2011 at 7:19 PM, joel278 <lehman.154@...> wrote:

> I feel like the central argument I proposed wasn't addressed: The optimal
> replicator, in terms of fitness, is likely some super-efficient bacteria. If
> biological fitness is the objective, then this super-bacteria is the global
> optima, this is what evolution should *stop* after it finds (as you propose
> in pole-balancing) -- anything else is worse, regardless of what strategy or
> resources it utilizes.
>

Actually, you (perhaps) are missing something.  Resource Constraint.  You
can only have so many organisms in a particular location.  Population
density plays a role in biological evolution, indirectly, because of its
role in survival.  An organism who evolves to occupy a different niche lives
to pass on its genes.

> Perhaps our discussion about objectives is merely semantic at this point.
>
Well, maybe, but there is a valid point to be made:  A poorly
stated/evaluated criteria creates limits on the evolution process.

> It is also interesting to consider whether environmental complexity, like
> Earth's richness, is a requirement for creating an open-ended complexifying
> evolutionary system.
>
Maybe.  Of course, using a fractal to approximate that complexity might be a
good, cheap alternative.  How to translate a fractal into an environment is
something for the imagination...


> I agree that competition is often localized within and between certain
> niches, Ken and I have a publication at GECCO this year related to that
> idea. But I think the larger point is that within these niches, a complex
> strategy is being discovered to do something that could ultimately be
> accomplished in a much simpler way; i.e. if the goal is reproduction, you
> can do it better by being a bacteria.
>

I question the assumption underlying that statement.

There was a bunch of research done recently about the economies of scale and
how that relates to biological organisms, and to cities and their size and
structure.  There is a definitive advantage to being a member cell of a
multi-cellular organism, just like there is an advantage to being a member
of society rather than having to grow your own food, make your own clothes,
be your own doctor, etc.  Being a lone single-celled organism is not
necessarily optimal in all cases.

-- 
John Arrowwood
--
http://www.irie-inc.com/
http://www.FindingResonance.com/

--00163641725d3146c404a0606c44
